headline.main-hed: Iraqi Government Forces Battle for Control of Major Oil Refinery

alt-summary-body.p: Iraq's elite counterterrorism units backed by other security forces and helicopter gunships were battling insurgents for control of the Beiji refinery.

headline.main-hed: Iraqi Government Forces Battle for Control of Major Oil Refinery
Iraq Battles for Control of Oil Refinery

summary-body.p: Iraq's elite counterterrorism units backed by other security forces and helicopter gunships were battling insurgents for control of the Beiji refinery.

list.list-item: Pentagon Cautions on Iraq Strikes | Video

headline.main-hed: Iraqi Government Forces Battle for Control of Major Oil Refinery
headline.deck: Elite Counterterrorism Units Battle Islamist Rebels for Control of Baiji Refinery

article-body.byline: By Ali A. Nabhan in Baghdad, Ellen Knickmeyer in Beirut and Sarah Kent in London

media.media-caption: Kurdish fighters attacked ISIS in Jalula and the militant group took partial control of an oil refinery in Beiji. Iranian President Hasan Rouhani said Iran will "spare no effort" in protecting Shiite sites in Iraq.

article-body.p: Iraq deployed counterterrorism units and helicopter gunships Wednesday to battle insurgents for control of the country's main oil refinery, as government forces intensified their efforts on multiple fronts to stem the progress of a powerful offensive by Sunni Muslim militants.

The gunships bombarded positions of the Islamic State of Iraq and al-Sham fighters inside the refinery in the northern city of Beiji that supplies Baghdad and much of the rest of the country with fuel, a state oil official said.
Two fuel-storage tanks were in flames after hours of fighting that erupted before dawn on Wednesday, when ISIS militants attacked with mortars and machine guns, another state oil official said.
The refinery's several hundred employees fled the facility as it came under the latest assault in the weeklong siege of the oil hub.

Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, appearing on state television, showed himself chastened by the military onslaught by ISIS and other Sunni militants that took the country's second-largest city, Mosul, and other cities and towns in the north before threatening central elements of the country's oil infrastructure. Thousands of Iraqi troops fled the militants' advance last week, allowing territory and weapons to fall into the insurgents' hands.

media.media-caption: A large plume of smoke rises from what is said to be Beiji oil refinery in Beiji, Iraq, in this still image taken from an amateur video posted on a social-media website on Wednesday.

list-item.link: Heard on the Street: Iraq Foretells Oil's Dystopian Future

media.media-caption: Iraq is on the brink of a full-blown civil war. Who are these ISIS jihadists and how do they hope to change the map of the Middle East? What do other countries like Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Jordan think about ISIS? WSJ's Jason Bellini diagrams the situation, and offers #TheShortAnswer.

Radical Sunni fighters, who seized another northern Iraqi city on Monday, are being aided by local tribes who reject the Islamists' extreme ideology but sympathize with their goal to oust Baghdad's Shiite-led government. WSJ's Matt Bradley joins Michael Casey on the News Hub to discuss. Photo: Getty

article-body.p: "What happened in Mosul was a shock for us," Mr. Maliki said. "The attack was painful, but now we are trying to stop the deterioration. The Iraqi people are being mobilized to take up arms against these gangs."

A military spokesman, Gen. Qassim Atta, insisted on Iraqiya state television that the Beiji refinery was under full government control, contradicting oil ministry officials and others who said the oil facility was at least partly in insurgent hands. By late Wednesday, ISIS fighters had retreated from the refinery complex to an adjacent compound for employees, ministry officials said.

Iraqi Foreign Minister Hoshyar Zebari said Wednesday that his country had requested U.S. airstrikes against ISIS. The Obama administration has said that it has no plans for airstrikes but was giving Iraq military and intelligence support, and urging political changes by Mr. Maliki's government to defuse the anger of minority Sunnis and others that feel marginalized under his Shiite-dominated government.

Although much of Iraq's oil production is in the south and remains safe from the insurgency in the north, the capture of the Beiji refinery and damage to Iraq's northern pipeline effectively cut off the Kirkuk oil field, which is under the control of Kurdish Peshmerga militiamen. The Beiji refinery has been closed since last week.

Without a supply of oil, ISIS would be unlikely to benefit from control of the refinery, said James F. Jeffery, a visiting fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy and a former U.S. envoy to Baghdad.
Still, shutting down the main source of refined fuel for Baghdad and many Sunni and Kurdish areas of Iraq could deepen sectarian tensions in the country.

"The lack of oil products is likely to further the misery and discontent and my prediction is that a lot of that will be directed toward the central government," said Mr. Jeffery, speaking during the CWC Iraq Petroleum conference in London.

The price of crude oil hasn't reacted specifically to the Beiji news, said Cuneyt Kazokoglu, an analyst at FACTS Global Energy in London, but with the refinery closed, Iraq's gasoline and diesel imports would likely increase.
Hundreds of ISIS fighters and their allies are battling to hold captured cities and seize more territory in their offensive against Mr. Maliki's Shiite-dominated government.

Iraq's Sunni minority accuses Mr. Maliki's government of systematic discrimination against Sunnis and other sects and political blocs. Some Sunni veterans of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's armed forces and Sunni tribal fighters also are participating in the offensive.
Iraq said government security forces were bolstering their numbers around the north Wednesday in a bid to recapture territory.

In Diyala province, directly to the north and east of Baghdad, an Iraqi government airstrike targeting a meeting of ISIS fighters killed 15 insurgents overnight, according to Abdul-Amier al Zaidi, the commander of a government command center. He said security forces were preparing a government offensive to reclaim the area of the attack, Udhaim, from ISIS fighters.

The Iraqi military was reinforcing its forces in the Diyala provincial capital, Baquba, after fighting near the city Tuesday. Authorities also reported fighting on Wednesday around the northwestern city of Tal Afar, after militants seized much of the city over the weekend, sending tens of thousands of residents fleeing. Iraqi television on Tuesday showed government reinforcements rolling to that battle.
Forces across Iraq continued mobilizing against ISIS.

Kurdistan's regional president, Massoud Barzani, urged retired Peshmerga fighters to report to their former military units. Jabar Yawar, secretary-general of the Peshmerga ministry, said the regional government had approximately 100,000 retired soldiers it would seek to muster to bolster the northern Kurdish region's "defensive line." He stressed, however, that the veterans were subject to an optional call-up, not conscription.

In Iran, President Hasan Rouhani said sought to warn off ISIS militants who have pledged attacks on Shiite shrines in Iraq's south.Iranian men were signing pledges to fight ISIS in Iraq and protect Shiite shrines., adding that Iraq had adequate numbers of volunteers. Limited numbers of Iranian forces already are in Iraq to help defend the Iraqi government and territory.

"Dear Karbala, dear Najaf, dear Kadhimiyah and dear Samarra, we warn the great powers and their lackeys and the terrorists, the great Iranian people will do everything to protect them," Mr. Rouhani said, naming some of the most religious sites most revered by Shiites. He spoke in the town of Khoramabad, near the Iraq border.
article-body.tagline: Joe Parkinson in Erbil and a correspondent in northern Iraq contributed to this article.

media.media-caption: A soldier waves the Iraqi flag as newly recruited men gather on Wednesday in the Shiite city of Najaf.

article-body.p: Write to Ellen Knickmeyer at ellen.knickmeyer@wsj.com and Sarah Kent at sarah.kent@wsj.com
